text:
East River, shore and skyline, Manhattan: The area above the Brooklyn Bridge, as photographed from the partially completed structure, showing the River, the waterfront and buildings in the Corlears Hook vicinity. In the center appears the peaked floating Seamen's Church. This is their third and is at the foot of Pike Slip. Market Slip is to the left, with the U. S. Bonded Warehouse to the west. The U. S. Naval Rendezvous Bank is at No. 452-4 Water Street. This was also known as the Seamens Exchange. Note the Hoe plant on Grand Street, in the background.

About 1876

Gift of the Seamen's Church Institute
title: East River - Shore and skyline - Manhattan - Corlears Hook.

text:
486-494 Water Street, north side, between Pike Slip and Rutgers Slip. Nos. 486-488 is a frame shack and wall enclosing a lumber yard. (Direction of Water Street is arbitrarily set to run east
and west).
April 16, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
The same, and showing a further view eastward to and including Rutgers Slip. Note the absence of No. 492-494 a 6-story tenement shown
in No. 1.
March 21, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Water Street - Pike Slip

title: Manhattan: Water Street - Pike Slip

text:
Water Street, north side, west from but not including Pike Slip. The view is taken from the Manhattan Bridge. The side of the building shown on the right is part of clearance from bridge construction and is not a street. The opposite side of the bridge
is Pike Slip. Breadline of mendicant's is shown.
June 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
The same, from a different angle.
July 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

text:
479-487 Water Street, south side, east of Pike Slip. No. 479-481 is a frame building.
1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

ASSUMING STREET TO BE EAST AND WEST
title: Manhattan: Water Street - Pike Slip

text:
(1)

472 to 478 Water Street (left to right), at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Pike Slip. Also shown are 77 to 71 Pike Slip, north from and including Water, to and including Cherry Streets.
March 30, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

A portion of the same, showing a closer view of Nos. 474-476.
March 30, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

The same as view No. 1, at a later date. Note the clearance on the N.E. corner of Pike Slip, and Cherry Street.
March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
Pike Slip, west side, north from, but not including Water Street, showing an anchorage of the Manhattan Bridge (left), at the N.W. corner of Cherry Street. The 6-story house and the 4-story stable adjoining it, (extreme left) the rears of which are shown, face on the south side of Monroe Street, and bear Nos. 75 and 78 respectively.

March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Pike Slip - Water Street

text:
(1)
Water Street, west from (No. 494) but not including Rutgers Slip, showing a lumber yard and scrap iron dump on the north side of the street (right) occupying the area from No. 504 (not shown) to 486 (6-story building). Also shown is a portion of the Manhattan Bridge.
March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A more limited view of No. 1, extending only to Pike Slip, but showing the lumber yard in its entirety.
March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A detail of view No. 2, showing the area from No. 496 to 500, the scrap-iron dump.
March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
